title: Talk of Higher Office Swirls Around Wisconsin Governor in the Spotlight
content:
“ After a year and a half of all this , I can ’ t imagine anything else but being focused here on Wisconsin , ” he said in an interview on Wednesday . But asked whether he was ruling out higher office forever , he said , “ It ’ s just daunting to think about anything else right now . ”
Mr. Walker ’ s profile clearly has already risen . His list of big donors in the recall election includes many outside Wisconsin , and prominent givers to other conservative causes : among them , Foster Friess , the Wyoming man who donated to a “ super PAC ” that kept Rick Santorum ’ s presidential hopes afloat ; Bob J. Perry , who helped pay for the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth ads against John Kerry eight years ago ; and Trevor Rees-Jones , the chairman of a Texas oil and gas company .
Several Republicans said Mr. Walker seemed unlikely to be seriously considered as , say , a vice-presidential possibility as early as this year . He is only now emerging from his own election and is not believed to have a long relationship with Mr. Romney , the presumed Republican presidential nominee . But Mr. Walker is building relationships outside the state , and has traveled around the country extensively over the past year , meeting with supporters in places like New York City and Palm Beach , Fla .
“ He received a hero ’ s welcome , ” Mr. Cardenas said of Mr. Walker ’ s appearance before the Conservative Political Action Conference this year . “ I sensed at the time that there ’ s something very special about the issues he ’ s tackling . I would say that after last night I believe he will be among the 10 most sought-after Republican speakers in the country . ”
Mr. Walker , 44 , is an Eagle Scout and the son of a Baptist preacher . He once lost a bid for class president at Marquette University , where he did not graduate . He was elected governor in 2010 after a long career in Wisconsin politics — as executive of Milwaukee County and a member of the State Assembly before that .

View all New York Times newsletters .
His approach , it seems , has always been the same . He is uncompromising , polarizing , headline-grabbing , austere . In Milwaukee County , he once proposed that the government might want to consider abolishing itself . There , he also pushed for privatizing cleaning and food service workers . He also pressed for changes to pension and health care contributions and workers ’ hours — a familiar theme when he became governor .
As governor , he has won praise from Tea Party members , traditional Republicans and abortion opponents . He signed provisions banning most abortion coverage in health care exchanges and barring doctors from conducting abortions remotely , via computer connections .
Along the campaign trail in recent months , his critics regularly raised questions about a criminal investigation that has already led to charges against aides and associates from the governor ’ s tenure as Milwaukee County executive , and that is continuing . The investigation has appeared to focus , at least in part , on whether county workers were performing political tasks on taxpayers ’ time .
For his part , Mr. Walker has said he is not a target of the investigation and is cooperating with prosecutors . But his opponents have pressed , with little success , for more details , especially after it was learned that he has transferred about $ 160,000 in campaign money to a fund being used to pay for legal expenses tied to the case .
Among Mr. Walker ’ s national supporters , some said they had not heard of the criminal investigation , and those who had said they suspected it was merely a barb from the campaign fight , not a long-term threat to his aspirations .
In Milwaukee on Wednesday , ordinary voters seemed unsurprised at the possibility that Mr. Walker is eyeing some higher office . “ His name is out there . People know who he is , ” said Charles Evans , who voted for Mr. Walker . “ I think he ’ s the poster child of aggressive reform . ”

“After a year and a half of all this, I can’t imagine anything else but being focused here on Wisconsin,” he said in an interview on Wednesday. But asked whether he was ruling out higher office forever, he said, “It’s just daunting to think about anything else right now.”

Mr. Walker’s profile clearly has already risen. His list of big donors in the recall election includes many outside Wisconsin, and prominent givers to other conservative causes: among them, Foster Friess, the Wyoming man who donated to a “super PAC” that kept Rick Santorum’s presidential hopes afloat; Bob J. Perry, who helped pay for the Swift Boat Veterans for Truth ads against John Kerry eight years ago; and Trevor Rees-Jones, the chairman of a Texas oil and gas company.

Several Republicans said Mr. Walker seemed unlikely to be seriously considered as, say, a vice-presidential possibility as early as this year. He is only now emerging from his own election and is not believed to have a long relationship with Mr. Romney, the presumed Republican presidential nominee. But Mr. Walker is building relationships outside the state, and has traveled around the country extensively over the past year, meeting with supporters in places like New York City and Palm Beach, Fla.

“He received a hero’s welcome,” Mr. Cardenas said of Mr. Walker’s appearance before the Conservative Political Action Conference this year. “I sensed at the time that there’s something very special about the issues he’s tackling. I would say that after last night I believe he will be among the 10 most sought-after Republican speakers in the country.”

Mr. Walker, 44, is an Eagle Scout and the son of a Baptist preacher. He once lost a bid for class president at Marquette University, where he did not graduate. He was elected governor in 2010 after a long career in Wisconsin politics — as executive of Milwaukee County and a member of the State Assembly before that.

His approach, it seems, has always been the same. He is uncompromising, polarizing, headline-grabbing, austere. In Milwaukee County, he once proposed that the government might want to consider abolishing itself. There, he also pushed for privatizing cleaning and food service workers. He also pressed for changes to pension and health care contributions and workers’ hours — a familiar theme when he became governor.

As governor, he has won praise from Tea Party members, traditional Republicans and abortion opponents. He signed provisions banning most abortion coverage in health care exchanges and barring doctors from conducting abortions remotely, via computer connections.

Along the campaign trail in recent months, his critics regularly raised questions about a criminal investigation that has already led to charges against aides and associates from the governor’s tenure as Milwaukee County executive, and that is continuing. The investigation has appeared to focus, at least in part, on whether county workers were performing political tasks on taxpayers’ time.

For his part, Mr. Walker has said he is not a target of the investigation and is cooperating with prosecutors. But his opponents have pressed, with little success, for more details, especially after it was learned that he has transferred about $160,000 in campaign money to a fund being used to pay for legal expenses tied to the case.

Among Mr. Walker’s national supporters, some said they had not heard of the criminal investigation, and those who had said they suspected it was merely a barb from the campaign fight, not a long-term threat to his aspirations.

In Milwaukee on Wednesday, ordinary voters seemed unsurprised at the possibility that Mr. Walker is eyeing some higher office. “His name is out there. People know who he is,” said Charles Evans, who voted for Mr. Walker. “I think he’s the poster child of aggressive reform.”
